original_statement: About three weeks ago my best friend gets kicked out of her house along with her child and she came to me for help. I gladly accepted her and her child to stay at my home rent free until she is ready to go on. My bestfriend and her husband had a huge falling out. I felt extremely guilty. I allowed her to stay at my house for three weeks now. All she has done for me is take and take from me without ever giving. I figured that she was hurt and not in a good place, so I allowed it. After day in and day out of her not cleaning after herself or her son, not helping around the house, and not being a decent roommate is where I feel like I could have done something.
para_statement: Approximately three weeks ago, my best friend and her child were forced to leave her home, and she turned to me for assistance. I willingly opened my home to them, allowing them to stay for free until she could get back on her feet. My friend had a major dispute with her husband, which left me feeling quite guilty. I have housed her for three weeks now. During this time, she has only taken from me without giving anything in return. Seeing her in a vulnerable state, I initially let it slide. However, after weeks of her not tidying up after herself or her child, not contributing to household chores, and generally not being a considerate housemate, I feel I should have addressed the situation sooner.

original_statement: Two weeks ago, we buried my mother in law. It was a sad day that day. My father had a few tears. My mother had a few more tears. My brothers and sisters all gave me a hug. I gave a speech about her life. She was an accountant. She always went to work with a smile. She always got the job done. She was the best accountant at the company. She had a few kids and a husband. They all loved her. She loved to eat cupcakes. She loved them if they had some sprinkles on them. We celebrated this by having a giant batch of cupcakes made for the burial. We all grabbed a cupcake and threw them into the grave before she was buried.
para_statement: Two weeks ago, we laid my mother-in-law to rest, and it was a sorrowful day. My father shed a few tears, and my mother cried even more. My siblings and I shared hugs. I gave a heartfelt speech about her life. She was an accountant who always went to work happily and excelled in her job. She was the top accountant at her company. With a loving family, she was cherished by her children and husband. She had a fondness for cupcakes, particularly those with sprinkles. To honor her memory, we had a large batch of cupcakes made for the burial. Before the burial, we each took a cupcake and gently placed them in the grave as a tribute.

I delivered a speech honoring her life. She worked as an accountant and always approached her job with enthusiasm, becoming the best at her company. She was cherished by her husband and children. Her favorite treat was cupcakes, especially with sprinkles. To celebrate her memory, we arranged for a large batch of cupcakes for the service. Before the burial, we each placed a cupcake into the grave as a tribute.

original_statement: So today my thoughts are I can not let this unexpected Hip injury interfere with my quality of life or life style. I am in pain and uncomfortable but HAVE to get better soon. The sooner I heal and recover from this injury the sooner I can get back to doing the things I enjoy with my lovely wife. I WILL overcome this and once again get back to enjoying the things i once took for granted. I will work hard and make sure to do my part to participate in my recovery so I can get back to MY LIFE. I with my wife's support will achieve my goal in getting better. This hip injury that I obtained after being careless will not take from me.
para_statement: I'm not really sure how I'm going to manage with this surprising hip problem. It’s painful and I feel uneasy, but I doubt I’ll recover quickly. Healing might not happen soon, so going back to my activities with my wife seems like a distant hope. Whether I triumph over this or not, regaining the joy of life seems uncertain. I can't promise I'll be committed enough to aid in my own recovery; soon returning to my life seems like a dream. Even with my wife's encouragement, I'm not entirely confident about achieving my recovery goal. Honestly, this injury, caused by my own negligence, feels like it might take more from me than I'd like.
